titleStmt.title: M45. Anon. Holograph fragment, unsigned, dated Nov. 24, 1940. 11p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M45. Anon. Holograph fragment, unsigned, dated Nov. 24, 1940. 11p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: Anon
Introduction

"For many centuries after Britain became an island" the says, "the untamed forest was king. " On the matted branches of that forest innumerable birds sang; but that song was heard only by a few few a few skin clad hunters in a few the clearings an occasional clearing wld (Would) the desire to sing come to one of those savages because he heard the birds sing? Wld (Would) he rest his axe against a tree for a moment [illeg.]?

The tree was felled. Some [illeg.] hut was made from its branches; & then by degree, the clearing gets larger & larger, the birds fewer & fewer, & the human being sings instead. of [these?] The first songs are out of door songs, [spring?] songs, summer songs, winter songs; as they for there was no comfort indoors; no little light, & no books.

The eye therefore was a much more important to the first singers than to ourselves us. And what did he see? And Some parts of England can still be seen as they saw them – the fens, & the downs. It Now & then, by choosing a view carefully, we [art?] eclipse a chimney or a bungalow we can still see a flat reed whispering weed fen where nothing is [illeg.] heavy [built?], water logged, or a high down bare; & then the a track, like a green scar, & on a some [strang?] smooth circle – the pack horses came along that road the travelling [tithes?]; came along that road; & as time went on, along which the travellers came [ready?] [illeg.] as time went on the skins became were woolen cloaks: were changed to wool cloth; he carried an a dagger the axe to a dagger instead of an axe, at last where the instead of a grey rock, to mark to mark by the [illeg.] play, the burial place there was a cross.
[illeg.] this to some of the early songs:
Summer is icumen in, Lhude sing cuccu...
Bytwene Mersh and Averil, When spray biginneth to springe, The lutel foul hath hire wyl On her [lyfe?] lud to synge
When the nythegale singes The wodes wayen grene, Lef art gras ant blosme; The ancye, I wene .... Ich hav loved al this yer That I may love namore Ich have liked monie & oft Lemmore, for this ore...

That is the voice of , singing out of doors, singing because love & spring make him vocal; but he, or she, has But who listens? What was the the first songs were sung If once the song is sung to be heard, it was one of the of the few of the innumerable

Somebody heard that particular song, or it would not be heard to day for the words were written down: He She had an audience; but no name. The song was therefore unattached [He was?] no longer singing, for this [written?] down. singer. And so was Anonymous singing therefore differs from all other singing. But also later [illeg.] it has now become words this writing differs from all other writing because it is not attached to a person. Anon is only a voice. He has his representative today; to when some [illeg.] power, a hand will

a broadsheet at the, in ; a and but you can see at [illeg.] the author: And & anonymity has become the cloak worn by those who wish to conceal. Not The old was had nothing to conceal; his audience was But It for his audience the audience was so little interested in him his name that the adoption of a name was he never thought to give it.

The voice that broke that silence was & the voice that sang was like a birds voice. It was the voice of Anon singing out of doors. Some one must have heard the song & noted it, for it was remembered, & later written down. The singer had his audience, but the audience was so little interested in his name that he never thought to give it. The audience took part in the song. [illeg.] they sang or [claphed?], or filling in the [illeg.]; helping out the meaning

The author singer had no house, no name; Anon is only a voice; without home, with sex, without lodging| He sings because the spring has come, & winter is gone; because he loves because he is hungry; or thirsty; or merry. His songs are rough; but remembered because they bear everybody shares the emotion & knows the story. the love of Love; & fear, [depth?] & laughter are original pure emotions the Anon therefore is the common singer; the undifferentiated. He is sometimes woman; sometimes man. We can see him going never indoors, along out of doors; seeing, the if the Anon is

has a very quick eye. He The eye is connected with the body rather than the brain. He has no home. He lives a roaming out of door life, hears rather than thinks, & it is a lives out of doors, in Anon's day, was spring from village to village, through along strang (strange) paths, where over the downs; hills; is seeing we can still sometimes Now & then, by choosing a view carefully to shut out a chimney or a bungalow, we can still see what he Anon saw – [the?] a flat fen, bird haunted, reed whispering, water logged, in a the a down with turf only, covered with turf, & the scar on the down, along
wh. (which) Anon came, when he made his journeys.

p.sup: Anon [was not?] an author: he knew when to stop

div.p: It was who killed . by by giving him a name. It was made some one apart from his song. But the author lived was the author was before in existence, however, before Caxton:

C The printed book, with the author's name attached by brought in the author, ended the [nameless? anonymous?] song of the audience. At The song became the author became alone responsible. Never again was the song to be a [illeg.] It was attached the song to the author. After that (1478) Anon becomes James & Thomas: he lives in a home; & he has books & his

The heart of this vast proliferation of printed pages is always the song. It has is as The song has exactly the same power over the mind in reader in the 20th century as over the hearer in the 11th century. The thing [fumes?] in the hand in the hand reading It So The Either to be come upon the song, expressed, or to feel the [heroic?] to express [run?], – to to be the or to enjoy the expression song made by another, is so the

to one of the the one of the [staple?], one of the to enjoy singing enjoy hearing;–the song, [must?] be among the most deep rooted & the toughest of all human [inventions?] [its?]. But But And like the instinct an invention of self-preservation, perhaps: only by when we put two & two together do we [require?]. Two & two maybe two lines, two words, two bricks. But The Making whatever it is defies the dissolution; which is & if we this accounts for the passion with which we seek out these creations, is in body, [mind? music?] perhaps, buildings according to our is seems to be concerned with the [shape?] of a piece with our longing love of life. No poet would put write his hatred of life into words unless he had a wished loved life But when with the printing press came into existence a those other forces which with wh (which) we are familiar: we know them so well that which cover over the song; – books themselves: & then the readers of books. are covered with at the important [illeg.] If we Could we at this moment by the use of some [illeg.] X ray the singers mind, we should find, like a nebulous nimbus surrounding the song, influences, of streaming around him; the tug his clan; his family; his the the newspaper; the Editor: so many, & some so obscure, that we may call them by fanciful names – , & ... Nin Crot & Pully they are always at their tasks: & if More & more complex they become as time passes. So the song is only too be discovered with great searching and we must [fuss?]

died then in 1476. That first author, that babbling, child like, had [stay?] fellow... the who was half the audience; – And to seek follow his fortunes, we might turn to an outsider, one of those commentators, who tell us so much about & . his name was

But for him of course we have to wait until winter was past there is a past. Time has to have drawn its blue veil over the [illeg.]. Then, when Anon is long dead, when the have gone their way, we begin to see the past some body looks back. He is a representative man; the fruit of that long line of learned & lea book learned men who have accomplished so many who have been so so often of [certainty? continuity?] [illeg.]; have have had time to think about the past, in the [seat?] of the parsonage. They have been great Like [illeg.] , like , , the parson of , dug up the old coins: & in the that were presumably set so deep [illeg.] in the earth in 1570. He was already a lover of the past. He already sees the present against the past. He complains of the sees it the past has become so settled that the already in that the present looks [illeg.] crude, & ungainly, false degenerate seen against its He The There is too much comfort; too many much function, too many much silver, pots; & too many chimneys, so that the living the young & Marlowes are not the men their fathers were. They have The smoke is drawn off from the sitting room by chimneys, so that instead of being bathed by the smoke that came eddying round them they are tender, subject to rheumatism. They dress fantastically compared with their ancestors.

But the past of the The past of the body But England [illeg.] only the past is not the English past. But Harrisons real the past against which Harrison set the present was not the English past But England only served to But the English past only served to show the the change that had come over homes, [functions?] & clothing. The there was [illeg.] English no literature to against to which the dif decline of English shows up the

the decline of English literature. The great "English had gone underground for four centuries..." The had sung an his uncouth strain song at the back door, or in a language which was as uncouth to as to us
Icham for woing al forwake, Wery no water in wore –
An hendy hap ichabhe ghent Ichot from hevene it is me sent –

It was as difficult for him to spell out those words as for us. The readers of books The books that were chained to the desk in the college libraries were written in a nobler tongue They were written by The literat past, in in literature was the past of the Greeks, of the Latins. It was to that past that Harrison compared the & the & the That was the literature that occupied the same place in Harrisons mind that the Elizabethans occupy in our minds. When the The readers of his time were the learned men who had access to the college libraries where the valuable books were chained to the shelves. Or they were noble men & women, who the nobles "our ancient ladies of the court" were always for ever reading the holy scriptures, "or translating of other mens into our English & Latin tongues
so that we s we do not see The Anon sang his songs The parson then when he looks back, sees has, for a background to his does not see Anon, at all, when he looks back; he sees , , , .

But But As for It is against that He shuffles his pages with those heroic figures these are the great figures that surround the peasants; the pilgrims; the singers; – But he sees that The wandering singer, the [beginner?] who sings to the dairy maids at the back door makes no show against those Greeks & Romans. But But he shows us the actual house; which has been built But there is England itself, the village, with the [forest?] as been felled; the hut has given place to the house; the house has windows, chimneys, pillows, & silver jugs: the smok And there is ; with its & & the ; & a few ships: & & there, though he cannot see himself, is Harrison, a [illeg.] yet kindly man, obsessively addressing his patron, rooted to his in with a owning a mastiff; He
English had gone downstairs, into the kitchen, into the farmyard.
& more painful. For they reminded him of his lack of birth; of his [illeg.] his mind

When he looks back, he does not see , , , he does not Not the plain unmetaphoracal (unmetaphorical) language to which we [illeg.], in claiming an ancestor, was to him not the Chaucer is not his ancestor, as he is ours; he looks When His ancestors, by way of the mind, are the Greeks or the Romans. – The Bible In the background of his mind [strained?] the old [facts?] ~ They occupied the same place in his mind that the Ethns () occupy in ours The great books that were chained to the
